nodes.text: A single-kernel, GPU-resident error-bounded lossy compression framework can achieve ultra-fast end-to-end throughput while also delivering high compression ratio and high reconstructed data quality for scientific HPC datasets

cuSZp implements a single-kernel, block-wise GPU compressor composed of four coordinated components (Quantization and Prediction, Fixed-length Encoding, Global Synchronization, Block Bit-shuffle) to realize high end-to-end performance

Quantization and Prediction: pre-quantize floating-point values to integers within the user error bound, then apply a lightweight 1D 1-layer Lorenzo prediction per block to convert integers into smaller reversible differences

Fixed-length Encoding per block: record sign map, take absolute values, compute the maximum absolute integer to determine a fixed bit-length F_k for the block, and compute block compressed size CmpL_k = (F_k + 1) * L / 8 bytes

Global Synchronization: implement exclusive prefix-sum of variable block compressed sizes in a hierarchical GPU scheme (thread-level, warp-level, global-level) inside the kernel to compute per-block offsets and total compressed size

Block Bit-shuffle: reorganize fixed-length encoded bits into aligned bytes by bit-offset across block elements and write shuffled bytes to final compressed memory using offsets from Global Synchronization

End-to-end performance result: on NVIDIA A100 across 6 representative scientific datasets, cuSZp achieves average end-to-end throughput 93.63 GB/s (compression) and 120.04 GB/s (decompression), representing 95.53x and 55.18x speedups versus cuSZ and cuSZx respectively

Kernel throughput and implementation evidence: cuSZp places all computation in one kernel so kernel throughput equals end-to-end throughput; hierarchical prefix-sum and register-level operations yield kernel throughput comparable to state-of-the-art (~100 GB/s or higher in many cases)

Compression ratio result: cuSZp attains the highest average compression ratio in 16 of 24 evaluated error-bound cases and often matches or exceeds cuSZ and cuSZx while constrained to single-kernel design

Data quality result: cuSZp preserves high reconstructed-data fidelity under error bounds (improved PSNR and SSIM versus cuZFP at similar bitrates) and avoids artifacts introduced by cuSZx fixed-block flushing in visualizations and isosurface renderings

Evaluation methodology: experiments run on NVIDIA A100 (CUDA 11.4) using 6 real-world HPC datasets (Hurricane, NYX, QMCPack, RTM, HACC, CESM-ATM), metrics include end-to-end throughput, kernel throughput, compression ratio, PSNR, SSIM, and visualization; baselines: cuSZ, cuSZx (error-bounded) and cuZFP (fixed-rate)
Limitation in comparison: cuSZ crashed on some tighter error bounds in evaluation due to implementation issues with storing Huffman codebooks, causing 'n/a' entries in some comparison cells

Conclusion: cuSZp demonstrates that a carefully designed single-kernel GPU error-bounded lossy compressor can deliver ultra-fast end-to-end throughput, competitive or superior compression ratios, and high reconstructed data quality; future work includes exploiting newer GPU architectures and integrating into live simulations
